text:
Sir,

I have been sometime in replying to the enclosed questionnaire, but not for granted your statement that there was no hurry.

In regards Questionnaire Nos. 3, 4 and 5. If it now seems well seen these, and I would be glad here an opportunity to relate my observations as I was very much alive in the work concerned.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

10-6 Well

P.O. Box 239, Saskatoon.

1918/64
Sir,

I have been sometime in replying to the enclosed questionnaire, but I fail to grasp your statement that there was no hurry.

In regard to questionnaires Nos. 3, 4, and 5, I do not know how well they answered my questions as I was very much obliged in this work concerned.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

P.O. Box 239, Saskatoon.
1918/64
Enclosed are three Archives questionnaires on pioneer schools, churches and recreation. During the past two years the Saskatchewan Archives Board has carried out a policy of distributing questionnaires to old-timers of the province, in order that experiences and events of pioneer life may be recorded and preserved, and we hope that you will assist in this enterprise.

These three questionnaires, No. 3 on pioneer schools, No. 4 on pioneer churches, and No. 5 dealing with recreation and social life, have been sent out as a group, since these are phases of pioneer life in which there was a distinct overlapping of activity. Each questionnaire is complete within itself, but by having the three of them to answer at the same time, it was thought that the person answering them would find it easier to avoid repetition from one questionnaire to another.

We realize that the answering of these will take some time, but you may be sure that your effort will be appreciated, and that all questionnaires which are completed and returned to the Archives Office are valued as part of the permanent record of our province, and provide an important source of information on early provincial settlement. If you wish, you may have someone else write your answers for you. If it is hard for you to write in English, it is quite all right to answer the questions in your own language.

Please give below the names and addresses of other pioneer who could answer these questionnaires. (You may send this form in with your completed questionnaires or may send this in now if you wish, and the questionnaires later).

I shall be obliged if all questionnaires could be sent.

Two other questionnaires which have been distributed within the past two years are still available; No. 1, "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat", and No. 2, "Pioneer Experiences: A General Questionnaire". If you have not completed these, please put a check mark below and they will be sent to you.

Please send me Archives Questionnaires No.1 and No. 2.

Send to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

Your name Windsor Charles Witt.
Address No 3 Orchard Grove.
Kesgrave, Ipswich.
England.
Province of Saskatchewan

Office of the Saskatchewan Archives

Enclosed are three Archives questionnaires on pioneer schools, churches and recreation. During the past two years the Saskatchewan Archives Board has carried out a policy of distributing questionnaires to old-timers of the province, in order that experiences and events of pioneer life may be recorded and preserved, and we hope that you will assist in this enterprise.

These three questionnaires; No. 3 on pioneer schools, No. 4 on pioneer churches, and No. 5 dealing with recreation and social life, have been sent out as a group, since there are phases of pioneer life in which there was a distinct overlapping of activity. Each questionnaire is complete within itself, but by having the three of them to answer at the same time, it was thought that the person answering them would find it easier to avoid repetition from one questionnaire to another.

We realize that the answering of these will take some time, but you may be sure that your effort will be appreciated, and that all questionnaires which are completed and returned to the Archives Office are valued as part of the permanent record of our province, and provide an important source of information on early provincial settlement. If you wish, you may have someone else write your answers for you. If it is hard for you to write in English, it is quite all right to answer the questions in your own language.

Please give below the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer these questionnaires. (You may send this form in with your completed questionnaires or may send this in now if you wish, and the questionnaires later.)

I shall be obliged if all questionnaires could be sent.

Two other questionnaires which have been distributed within the past two years are still available; No. 1, "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" and No. 2, "Pioneer Experience: A General Questionnaire". If you have not completed these, please put a check mark below and they will be sent to you.

Please send me Archives Questionnaires No.1 and No. 2.

Send to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

Your name ___________________________
Address ___________________________
______________________________

Windsor Charles Witt
No. 3 Windsor Grove
Kesgrave Ipswich
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pionser Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (✓) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as everyone else. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience at all; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about answering them. Others may prove too irrelevant or too personal to answer.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pilot: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still circulating. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Some of the Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be posted at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark those that you are willing to answer.

All questionnaires:

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sport and recreation
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of our Provincial Archives. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ........................................... Mr. Windsor Charles Witt
2. Your address .................................................. Orchard Grove Kesgrave Ipswich England
3. Date ............................................................ .
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Breanmore No Salisbury England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Harry Witt Small Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) April 1903
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Bath Somerset Eng.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   I WAS IN MY TEENS.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   I WAS FULL OF THE DESIRE TO EMIGRATE
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    At school, reading, government information.

RECEIVED OCT 28 1954 SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVER ASHFORD
Witt, Windsor Charles
3 Crofton Grove, Rosegrove, Ipswich, England.

1903.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Mr. WINDSOR CHARLES M.T.T.
2. Your address: 3 CROFTON GROVE, IPSWICH, ENGLAND.
3. Data:
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): BRENTWOOD, ENGLAND.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): APRIL 1903.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

BATH SOMERSET Etc.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens", etc.) I WAS IN MY TEENS.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

I WAS FULL OF THE DESIRE TO EMIGRATE

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

READING GOVERNMENT INFORMATION.

At SCHOOL
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

All were happy about it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I entered Canada as a member of the Barr Colony.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We traveled by the Lake Manitoba Elder V Demoster Line.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Colonist cars left St. Johns Easter Sunday evening. Arrived Saskatoon following Saturday morning. Small lakes were still frozen in Western Ontario. The Saskatchewan River was still frozen over. It broke up the following week.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We lived in bell tents on the west side of the tracks. Nights were cold. A circular ring was dug, 16 inches deep. The mound in the centre was left on this the fire was made. Cord wood was supplied by the immigration officer.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Took up homestead near Blucher, New Sec 24 Township 28 Range 2 W.M.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

First worked for Charlie Kesch, east of town. Then did some rail road work, had 8 months in roundhouse became junior fireman. After started work for Leslie Wilson & floor mill on west side. Stayed there till started residence duties on farm. Built first elevator at Blucher. Managed that till I finished & got my title deed. Did more railroad work on bridge & building deal.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Opened up fire insurance for Saskatoon Mutual Fire Ins Co Manager Mr Charles Smith, son of Henry Smith, Smithville.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

All were happy about it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I entered Canada as a member of the Boer Colony.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We traveled by train from Manitoba to Edmonton.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement.)

- Chariot Grass (near St. Thomas, Eastern Sunday evening)
- Harvested Saskatchewan following Saturday morning
- Small lakes were still frozen in Western Ontario
- The Saskatchewan River was still frozen over. It broke up the following week.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We lived in bell tents on the west side of the tracks.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Took up homestead near Bauchet, New Sec. 24, Township 25, Range 27.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Forest worked for Charlie Koest, east of Town. Two and a half years.

Road work, had eight months in Flin Flon, Manitoba. Worked in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario. After started work at Esdale Wilson Elevator in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario. Then started residence at that time finished school. My title deed, did some farming on Bruce's building. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Opened up fire insurance for Saskatchewan Victoria Fire Ins. Manager Mr. Charles Smith, Sault Ste. Marie, Sault Ste. Marie.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

OFTEN. They were kept fully informed, and we always lived on good terms.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

I was not married till the end of World War No. 1. I was married in England. Halls House-Keeping near London raised a family of 4.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

3 cousins came and settled in Saskatchewan. Most of land in early part of century, and claimed.

A schoolmate came also worked in Regina.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

ONE brother came up from Oregon. He after a time went and farmed on Vancouver Island at Sayward. Then Port Kootenay.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I moved about the province in my work from Regina to P. Albert, Neudorf and Humbert, Baseline Lake westbound to Goose Lake, then I spent several days with Mr. Fred Engen before the land was surveyed. I journeyed in local Sack selling firewood during an 8 weeks tour. I drove an old buckboard pulled by a very dilapidated horse & stayed nine nights overnight the first night quite safe to leave the house for half hour and talk to a farmer 200 yards away. I came along to town for dinner. Engen joined Adams moving northward to Cathcart Road to Red deer. Engen joined Adams moving northward to Cathcart Road to Red deer.

Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

I moved northward through Pennsylvania, little time remains since twenty day July 1. The reserve was empty but for 1 square. I looked in the windows of the numerous log houses—no one the Square was squinting on the floors—not a soul was said by either of us. The bridge across the Battle River was worth was said by either of us. The bridge across the Battle River was worth while we were still in bed. Thus the broken bridge touched the Cottage. The river was two feet deep. Thus the broken bridge touched the Cottage. I walked across carefully, then decided the horse & buckboard had better be left behind. Finally we reached the other side safely between the Battle river & Bessie. The Indians were having a native fête.

I joined in & spent several hours with them.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, how many?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? How often? How far? By what means or travel?
25. When was the first car used in the community? about 1907-8

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? To car

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Saskatoon was trading center for Cluny, I.C. Co., Grandview, M. Schlicht, Hardwood, P.C. Carver, J.P. Carver, Grandview, Osmo & Kempton, Hardwood, Acton, Macintosh, Lumber, M. Sutton, brick center, Hotel, Ralph Hill photographer.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

At Buecher where homestead was located, J.S. Larley kept a store through. Continued to buy from J.P. Carver, Saskatoon. Homesteaders bought about a month's supply, later, when the railroad came through, more cotton bought locally, delivering a load of wheat, returning with supplies. Coal was bought locally, but we had no road past. We rode north, 2-3 day trip. I worked in conjunction with Hugh M. Kenyon and Jack MacKenzie helping with the harvest, loading wood, and jobs requiring an extra hand.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

Once a month

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

They never started on my time. We went west through at 2 a.m. summer, winter, it was not encouraged to go to town especially when the road was bad for an outside team.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the phone era began.

Very little from T. Eaton, Winnipeg.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

No telephone

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

I always liked Saskatchewan. I liked the idea of permanent settlement here. Conditions were uncertain, I wouldn't neglect myself or allow myself to be left behind as a single man, hence I kept moving. My work as a clerk helped keep me active during fall and winter, hence I moved to BC for what longer. Kept me active during fall and winter, hence I moved to BC for what longer. I stayed till 1914 over, then I joined up again over 3 years in militia, I stayed till 1914 over, then I joined up again over 3 years in militia, I joined 29th Battalion, No. 75654.
25. When was the first car used in the community? about 1901-8

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes it?

27. Where was your traveling agency? How far from your home? J. F. C. Co., Kemptown, Saskatchewan.

28. Did you continue to travel there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? once a month

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

34. I always thought...
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some people moved out, some better educated got jobs with good pay on the coast. Most were bound to their farms by laws and family life and kept activity improving until better times arrived.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

I was not in Saskatchewan then.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was an active Liberal and was a member of the Saskatchewan Committee. I was then in the Northern Committee. Mr. Lamont was elected. He attended Nelson, Judge Lamont. That was before the two provinces came into Confederation. Mr. Wallis Scott Riggs' name was appended to the first premier, Mr. Maclean. Apparently he wanted the first Premier later. Mr. Maclean became leader of the Opposition. I attended the old legislature and helped K.T. Dobbin. The general standard of discourse was poor. The No. 2 leaders were competent. George Douglas was a member for Rosser. Provided the humour.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

I am the first elected at Blucher station. I stood up quite an aura of credit. A local landholder, pioneering for insurance for livestock market. My name had called on them before. It was difficult even then. To extract the few remaining dollars from the old-timer who handled everything with cash. I was pleased at founding store buying. Millwood Church 2nd Avenue and was a member. It became so small, a new one was built.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given (5) date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1) & (2), (3).

Blucher was named after John Brown after whom Mr. McKeown called himself. Named after T. McKenzie & Hugh McKenzie (brothers) farmers in adjoining farms. Blucher derived its name from Mr. McKeown's part of the name. Wellington presumably as there was another P.O. of that name. The authorities don't know the name Blucher.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1934? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were military to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates (such as coming to the first automobile, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, military stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person (a) any changes in names since origin, and then name was given; (2) date of its adoption; (3) date and reason for change.

39. What other names have been used for this place?
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

I cannot reply to any

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?.... (indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

I am father of 4 children as follows according to age:
Married - Daughter Mrs. Edith Witt, 95 Best Hamlet, Spared, by:
Married - Son-in-law Mr. John Montague Witt, 60 years of age
Married - Son Paul Alexander Witt, 20 years of age
Married - Son-in-law Mr. John Montague Witt, 60 years of age
Married - Daughter Astrid Witt, 17 years of age

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The general increase in population within the province, more people because of the roads and telephone development. The quality of cattle being shown at the summer exhibition.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

Filled in entirely by the above

W. T. Witt, 3 Orchard Grove, Keagans, Spence, Eng
6. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old photos, written recollections and reminiscences? (Please list)

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, or the Archives Office at the University of Saskatchewan?

(Indicate your preference, if any)

49. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

I am the child of Mr. and Mrs. John Smith.

51. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

The greatest change has been the development of the new shopping center.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here.

[Signature]

[Signature]
Oxford

No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.

Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
